column2: When the ship moved out upon the water, those who stayed behind, Chee-Chee, Polynesia and the crocodile, grew terribly sad.
column3: When the ship moved out upon the water, those who stayed behind, Chee Chee, Polynesia and the crocodile, grew terribly sad.

column2: For never in their lives had they known any one they liked so well as Doctor John Dolittle of Puddleby-on-the-Marsh.
column3: For never in their lives had they known any one they liked so well as Doctor john Dolittle of Puddleby on the Marsh.

column2: And after they had called Good-by to him again and again and again, they still stood there upon the rocks, crying bitterly and waving till the ship was out of sight.
column3: And after they had called Good by to him again and again and again, they still stood there upon the rocks, crying bitterly and waving till the ship was out of sight.

column2: THE THIRTEENTH CHAPTER
column3: THE THIRTEENTH CHAPTER

column2: RED SAILS AND BLUE WINGS
column3: RED SAILS AND BLUE WINGS

column2: SAILING homeward, the Doctor's ship had to pass the coast of Barbary. This coast is the seashore of the Great Desert.
column3: SAILING homeward, the Doctor's ship had to pass the coast of Barbary. This coast is the seashore of the Great Desert.

column2: It is a wild, lonely place--all sand and stones.
column3: It is a wild, lonely place-all sand and stones.

column2: And it was here that the Barbary pirates lived.
column3: And it was here that the Barbary pirates lived.

column2: These pirates, a bad lot of men, used to wait for sailors to be shipwrecked on their shores.
column3: These pirates, a bad lot of men, used to wait for sailors to be shipwrecked on their shores.

column2: And often, if they saw a boat passing, they would come out in their fast sailing-ships and chase it.
column3: And often, if they saw a boat passing, they would come out in their fast sailing ships and chase it.

column2: When they caught a boat like this at sea, they would steal everything on it; and after they had taken the people off they would sink the ship and sail back to Barbary singing songs and feeling proud of the mischief they had done.
column3: When they caught a boat like this at sea, they would steal everything on it; and after they had taken the people off they would sink the ship and sail back to Barbary singing songs and feeling proud of the mischief they had done.

column2: Then they used to make the people they had caught write home to their friends for money.
column3: Then they used to make the people they had caught write home to their friends for money.

column2: And if the friends sent no money, the pirates often threw the people into the sea.
column3: And if the friends sent no money, the pirates often threw the people into the sea.

column2: Now one sunshiny day the Doctor and Dab-Dab were walking up and down on the ship for exercise; a nice fresh wind was blowing the boat along, and everybody was happy.
column3: Now one sunshiny day the Doctor and Dab Dab were walking up and down on the ship for exercise; a nice fresh wind was blowing the boat along, and everybody was happy.

column2: Presently Dab-Dab saw the sail of another ship a long way behind them on the edge of the sea.
column3: Presently Dab Dab saw the sail of another ship a long way behind them on the edge of the sea.

column2: It was a red sail.
column3: It was a red sail.

column2: I don't like the look of that sail, said Dab-Dab.
column3: I don't like the look of that sail, said Dab Dab.

column2: I have a feeling it isn't a friendly ship.	I have a feeling it isn't a friendly ship.
column3: true

column2: I am afraid there is more trouble coming to us."
column3: I am afraid there is more trouble coming to us."

column2: Jip, who was lying near taking a nap in the sun, began to growl and talk in his sleep.
column3: Jip, who was lying near taking a nap in the sun, began to growl and talk in his sleep.

column2: I smell roast beef cooking, he mumbled--"underdone roast beef--with brown gravy over it."
column3: I smell roast beef cooking, he mumbled-"underdone roast beef-with brown gravy over it."

column2: Good gracious! cried the Doctor.
column3: Good gracious! cried the Doctor.

column2: What's the matter with the dog? Is he SMELLING in his sleep--as well as talking?
column3: What's the matter with the dog? Is he SMELLING in his sleep-as well as talking?

column2: I suppose he is, said Dab-Dab.
column3: I suppose he is, said Dab Dab.

column2: All dogs can smell in their sleep.
column3: All dogs can smell in their sleep.

column2: But what is he smelling? asked the Doctor.
column3: But what is he smelling? asked the Doctor.

column2: There is no roast beef cooking on our ship. "No," said Dab-Dab.
column3: There is no roast beef cooking on our ship. "No," said Dab Dab.

column2: The roast beef must be on that other ship over there.
column3: The roast beef must be on that other ship over there.

column2: But that's ten miles away, said the Doctor.
column3: But that's ten miles away, said the Doctor.

column2: He couldn't smell that far surely!
column3: He couldn't smell that far surely!

column2: Oh, yes, he could, said Dab-Dab.
column3: Oh, yes, he could, said Dab Dab.

column2: You ask him.
column3: You ask him.

column2: Then Jip, still fast asleep, began to growl again and his lip curled up angrily, showing his clean, white teeth.
column3: Then Jip, still fast asleep, began to growl again and his lip curled up angrily, showing his clean, white teeth.

column2: I smell bad men, he growled--"the worst men I ever smelt.
column3: I smell bad men, he growled-"the worst men I ever smelt.

column2: I smell trouble.
column3: I smell trouble.

column2: I smell a fight--six bad scoundrels fighting against one brave man.
column3: I smell a fight-six bad scoundrels fighting against one brave man.

column2: I want to help him.
column3: I want to help him.

column2: Woof--oo--WOOF!"
column3: Woof-oo-WOOF!"

column2: Then he barked, loud, and woke himself up with a surprised look on his face.
column3: Then he barked, loud, and woke himself up with a surprised look on his face.

column2: See! cried Dab-Dab.
column3: See! cried Dab Dab.

column2: That boat is nearer now.	That boat is nearer now.
column3: true

column2: You can count its three big sails--all red.
column3: You can count its three big sails-all red.

column2: Whoever it is, they are coming after us....
column3: Whoever it is, they are coming after us....

column2: I wonder who they are."
column3: I wonder who they are."

column2: They are bad sailors, said Jip; "and their ship is very swift.
column3: They are bad sailors, said Jip; "and their ship is very swift.

column2: They are surely the pirates of Barbary."
column3: They are surely the pirates of Barbary."

column2: Well, we must put up more sails on our boat, said the Doctor, "so we can go faster and get away from them.
column3: Well, we must put up more sails on our boat, said the Doctor, "so we can go faster and get away from them.

column2: Run downstairs, Jip, and fetch me all the sails you see."
column3: Run downstairs, Jip, and fetch me all the sails you see."

column2: The dog hurried downstairs and dragged up every sail he could find.
column3: The dog hurried downstairs and dragged up every sail he could find.

column2: But even when all these were put up on the masts to catch the wind, the boat did not go nearly as fast as the pirates'--which kept coming on behind, closer and closer.
column3: But even when all these were put up on the masts to catch the wind, the boat did not go nearly as fast as the pirates'--which kept coming on behind, closer and closer.

column2: This is a poor ship the Prince gave us, said Gub-Gub, the pig--"the slowest he could find, I should think.
column3: This is a poor ship the Prince gave us, said Gub Gub, the pig-"the slowest he could find, I should think.

column2: Might as well try to win a race in a soup-tureen as hope to get away from them in this old barge.
column3: Might as well try to win a race in a soup tureen as hope to get away from them in this old barge.

column2: Look how near they are now!-- You can see the mustaches on the faces of the men--six of them.
column3: Look how near they are now!-- You can see the mustaches on the faces of the men-six of them.

column2: What are we going to do?"
column3: What are we going to do?"

column2: Then the Doctor asked Dab-Dab to fly up and tell the swallows that pirates were coming after them in a swift ship, and what should he do about it.
column3: Then the Doctor asked Dab Dab to fly up and tell the swallows that pirates were coming after them in a swift ship, and what should he do about it.

column2: When the swallows heard this, they all came down on to the Doctor's ship; and they told him to unravel some pieces of long rope and make them into a lot of thin strings as quickly as he could.
column3: When the swallows heard this, they all came down on to the Doctor's ship; and they told him to unravel some pieces of long rope and make them into a lot of thin strings as quickly as he could.

column2: Then the ends of these strings were tied on to the front of the ship; and the swallows took hold of the strings with their feet and flew off, pulling the boat along.
column3: Then the ends of these strings were tied on to the front of the ship; and the swallows took hold of the strings with their feet and flew off, pulling the boat along.

column2: And although swallows are not very strong when only one or two are by themselves, it is different when there are a great lot of them together.
column3: And although swallows are not very strong when only one or two are by themselves, it is different when there are a great lot of them together.

column2: And there, tied to the Doctor's ship, were a thousand strings; and two thousand swallows were pulling on each string--all terribly swift fliers.
column3: And there, tied to the Doctor's ship, were a thousand strings; and two thousand swallows were pulling on each string-all terribly swift fliers.

column2: And in a moment the Doctor found himself traveling so fast he had to hold his hat on with both hands; for he felt as though the ship itself were flying through waves that frothed and boiled with speed.
column3: And in a moment the Doctor found himself traveling so fast he had to hold his hat on with both hands; for he felt as though the ship itself were flying through waves that frothed and boiled with speed.

column2: And all the animals on the ship began to laugh and dance about in the rushing air, for when they looked back at the pirates' ship, they could see that it was growing smaller now, instead of bigger.
column3: And all the animals on the ship began to laugh and dance about in the rushing air, for when they looked back at the pirates' ship, they could see that it was growing smaller now, instead of bigger.

column2: The red sails were being left far, far behind.
column3: The red sails were being left far, far behind.
